Two things can be true at once. Vaccines can work (depending on which one you are talking about) and they can be dangerous. The mechanism of vaccination has proven to work, that's not the question for people who are concerned about vaccines. If the immune system catches rabies in the nerve that controls a major muscle, can that cause temporary loss of control over that muscle? The reason I ask is that I had to get rabies shots when I was a child because I was bit by a presumably rabid dog behind my leg tearing tendon. It happened because a school bus was a few hours late. While it hurt to move I had muscle control, but after one of the rabies shots I temporarily lost control over my leg muscle. My mother thought I was making it up and dragged me inside. I was scared though since I lost feeling in my leg, but feeling returned within a few hours. Afterwards I ran away from home so that I would miss the rest of the shots.

Now, looking back, I don't think the vaccine itself caused the temporary paralysis, but I wonder if the rabies virus happened to be in a major nerve in my left leg and then when my immune system learned to recognize it due to the vaccine maybe while it was attacking the virus something happened like inflammation to temporarily inhibit function, but I'm just guessing.

Fun fact for anyone who cares: about 15yrs ago neuroscientists developed a way to use deactivated lyssavirus to trace neural connections in the brains of animal models they study. In the future, it may be used to deliver gene therapies into the brains of people suffering from debilitating mental disorders.

COPYPASTA

Rabies. It's exceptionally common, but people just don't run into the animals that carry it often. Skunks especially, and bats.

Let me paint you a picture.

You go camping, and at midday you decide to take a nap in a nice little hammock. While sleeping, a tiny brown bat, in the "rage" stages of infection is fidgeting in broad daylight, uncomfortable, and thirsty (due to the hydrophobia) and you snort, startling him. He goes into attack mode.

Except you're asleep, and he's a little brown bat, so weighs around 6 grams. You don't even feel him land on your bare knee, and he starts to bite. His teeth are tiny. Hardly enough to even break the skin, but he does manage to give you the equivalent of a tiny scrape that goes completely unnoticed.

Rabies does not travel in your blood. In fact, a blood test won't even tell you if you've got it. (Antibody tests may be done, but are useless if you've ever been vaccinated.)

You wake up, none the wiser. If you notice anything at the bite site at all, you assume you just lightly scraped it on something.

The bomb has been lit, and your nervous system is the wick. The rabies will multiply along your nervous system, doing virtually no damage, and completely undetectable. You literally have NO symptoms.

It may be four days, it may be a year, but the camping trip is most likely long forgotten. Then one day your back starts to ache... Or maybe you get a slight headache?

At this point, you're already dead. There is no cure.

(The sole caveat to this is the Milwaukee Protocol, which leaves most patients dead anyway, and the survivors mentally disabled, and is seldom done).

There's no treatment. It has a 100% kill rate.

Absorb that. Not a single other virus on the planet has a 100% kill rate. Only rabies. And once you're symptomatic, it's over. You're dead.

So what does that look like?

Your headache turns into a fever, and a general feeling of being unwell. You're fidgety. Uncomfortable. And scared. As the virus that has taken its time getting into your brain finds a vast network of nerve endings, it begins to rapidly reproduce, starting at the base of your brain... Where your "pons" is located. This is the part of the brain that controls communication between the rest of the brain and body, as well as sleep cycles.

Next you become anxious. You still think you have only a mild fever, but suddenly you find yourself becoming scared, even horrified, and it doesn't occur to you that you don't know why. This is because the rabies is chewing up your amygdala.

As your cerebellum becomes hot with the virus, you begin to lose muscle coordination, and balance. You think maybe it's a good idea to go to the doctor now, but assuming a doctor is smart enough to even run the tests necessary in the few days you have left on the planet, odds are they'll only be able to tell your loved ones what you died of later.

You're twitchy, shaking, and scared. You have the normal fear of not knowing what's going on, but with the virus really fucking the amygdala this is amplified a hundred fold. It's around this time the hydrophobia starts.

You're horribly thirsty, you just want water. But you can't drink. Every time you do, your throat clamps shut and you vomit. This has become a legitimate, active fear of water. You're thirsty, but looking at a glass of water begins to make you gag, and shy back in fear. The contradiction is hard for your hot brain to see at this point. By now, the doctors will have to put you on IVs to keep you hydrated, but even that's futile. You were dead the second you had a headache.

You begin hearing things, or not hearing at all as your thalamus goes. You taste sounds, you see smells, everything starts feeling like the most horrifying acid trip anyone has ever been on. With your hippocampus long under attack, you're having trouble remembering things, especially family.

You're alone, hallucinating, thirsty, confused, and absolutely, undeniably terrified. Everything scares the literal shit out of you at this point. These strange people in lab coats. These strange people standing around your bed crying, who keep trying to get you "drink something" and crying. And it's only been about a week since that little headache that you've completely forgotten. Time means nothing to you anymore. Funny enough, you now know how the bat felt when he bit you.

Eventually, you slip into the "dumb rabies" phase. Your brain has started the process of shutting down. Too much of it has been turned to liquid virus. Your face droops. You drool. You're all but unaware of what's around you. A sudden noise or light might startle you, but for the most part, it's all you can do to just stare at the ground. You haven't really slept for about 72 hours.

Then you die. Always, you die.

And there's not one... fucking... thing... anyone can do for you.

Then there's the question of what to do with your corpse. I mean, sure, burying it is the right thing to do. But the fucking virus can survive in a corpse for years. You could kill every rabid animal on the planet today, and if two years from now, some moist, preserved, rotten hunk of used-to-be brain gets eaten by an animal, it starts all over.

So yeah, rabies scares the shit out of me.

Speaking from personal experience, do trust the science! Back in 2014 my cat was fighting with a stray cat and my dad bravely pulled them apart. (Yes, I know you're not supposed to separate cat/dog fights but my cat would have died had he not pulled them apart.) My dad got a really bad and deep bite on his hand by the stray cat. Unfortunately the stray cat ran off and we couldn't catch or find him, so we presumed it was rabid given how aggressive it was and it didn't have a collar. The only place they give post-exposure rabies shots is at the ER. Sure enough, he had to make multiple appointments and it was incredibly painful. He had to get 3 shots just at the exposure site on his hand, probably another 2-3 in his abdomen. Not fun, very painful, and expensive. But, I'm so very glad that the treatment was readily available to him. He very well could have died without that treatment. He's living life now though as if it never happened!

My cat is also fine, thankfully up to date with his rabies shots. Get your pets vaccinated/keep their shots updated! Don't hesitate to get the shots if you feel like you've been exposed, it's not worth the risk.

The Milwaukee Protocol was, at one point, theorized as our best chance to combat rabies once it entered the body in the event that it was too late for the vaccine but before advanced symptoms developed. The idea was to put the patient in a medically induced coma and being pumped with antivirals as well as other drugs such as Ketamine. The suppressed brain activity would essentially slow the spread of the virus which would provide the body with extra time to combat the viral infection.

While it worked in one case which became the first known survival of rabies it also failed in over two-dozen other attempts and is only seen as a last resort.

I doubt the claim that you are most likely to contract rabies from a rabid dog bite is actually true for the demographic of "people who watched this video," or for the Youtube audience in general.
In the US, which comprises the largest viewership of any country for this channel, the vast, vast majority of rabies cases stem from bats. Cases from rabid dogs are exceptionally rare in the US. This holds for most if not all of the developed world. Given that, the claim that you would contract rabies "most likely from a dog" is very much false for almost everyone who watches this video.

A few points:
1) Up to 2004 no person had survived rabies after the onset of symptoms. However, since that time 29 people have survived through new techniques such as The Milwaukee Protocol. Still, when you consider that over 55,000 people die from rabies each year, 29 survivors in 18 years still means that rabies is almost 100% fatal after the onset of symptoms.
2) Birds have been found to carry rabies antibodies, showing that they’ve been infected. However they never become symptomatic.
3) At one point near the end, you imply (with a picture) that squirrels may be rabid. While this is possible since squirrels are mammals, it would be an extremely rare event, because any squirrel that’s bitten by a rabid animal will very likely die immediately. This is why rabies is more common in larger mammals, which can be bitten but survive long enough for the virus to incubate.

. . . Okay, I'm not an epidemiologist. I am not an expert in infectious disease but I do consider myself a polished amateur because I find them fascinating, read a fair amount of research on them, and have friends that are experts who discuss their work with me on a regular basis.

I would also say that this might be needlessly pedantic, but with this video getting a lot of traction and millions of people watching it, I feel it's important to correct something if it's wrong.

Rabies is not "the deadliest virus known to man" as it is stated in the video. Yes, it sounds good in the video but it's not true. It has an almost 100% guarantee of death if it's not caught in time, but especially today it's not nearly as large of an issue (India and parts of Africa excluded due to the lack of available treatment and preventive care) due to vaccines and antibodies. The deadliest virus would change depending on what metric you choose to select it. Actual deaths? Death rate? Across time or just in the modern day? Do we include only humans in our choice or are we including diseases that also infect other animals as well? Even then, HIV for example (kills almost a million people every year) has only ever had three people been cured. Rabies on the other hand kills about 59,000 (which they rounded up in the video, I'm guessing because 60k just sounds better) a year and has a vaccine that can be administered even after infection.

So while it's nice to simplify things, it shouldn't be done in a way that could misinform people. Nor should information ever be used as a scare tactic, as it is in this video. Things are complicated, and it's not hard to convey the complexity of our world without getting caught in the weeds when teaching people that are less knowledgeable in a topic.

Since i haven't seen the infamous copypasta anywhere in this comment section, i'll post here:

Rabies. It's exceptionally common, but people just don't run into the animals that carry it often. Skunks especially, and bats.

Let me paint you a picture.

You go camping, and at midday you decide to take a nap in a nice little hammock. While sleeping, a tiny brown bat, in the "rage" stages of infection is fidgeting in broad daylight, uncomfortable, and thirsty (due to the hydrophobia) and you snort, startling him. He goes into attack mode.

Except you're asleep, and he's a little brown bat, so weighs around 6 grams. You don't even feel him land on your bare knee, and he starts to bite. His teeth are tiny. Hardly enough to even break the skin, but he does manage to give you the equivalent of a tiny scrape that goes completely unnoticed.

Rabies does not travel in your blood. In fact, a blood test won't even tell you if you've got it. (Antibody tests may be done, but are useless if you've ever been vaccinated.)

You wake up, none the wiser. If you notice anything at the bite site at all, you assume you just lightly scraped it on something.

The bomb has been lit, and your nervous system is the wick. The rabies will multiply along your nervous system, doing virtually no damage, and completely undetectable. You literally have NO symptoms.

It may be four days, it may be a year, but the camping trip is most likely long forgotten. Then one day your back starts to ache... Or maybe you get a slight headache?

At this point, you're already dead. There is no cure.

(The sole caveat to this is the Milwaukee Protocol, which leaves most patients dead anyway, and the survivors mentally disabled, and is seldom done).

There's no treatment. It has a 100% kill rate.

Absorb that. Not a single other virus on the planet has a 100% kill rate. Only rabies. And once you're symptomatic, it's over. You're dead.

So what does that look like?

Your headache turns into a fever, and a general feeling of being unwell. You're fidgety. Uncomfortable. And scared. As the virus that has taken its time getting into your brain finds a vast network of nerve endings, it begins to rapidly reproduce, starting at the base of your brain... Where your "pons" is located. This is the part of the brain that controls communication between the rest of the brain and body, as well as sleep cycles.

Next you become anxious. You still think you have only a mild fever, but suddenly you find yourself becoming scared, even horrified, and it doesn't occur to you that you don't know why. This is because the rabies is chewing up your amygdala.

As your cerebellum becomes hot with the virus, you begin to lose muscle coordination, and balance. You think maybe it's a good idea to go to the doctor now, but assuming a doctor is smart enough to even run the tests necessary in the few days you have left on the planet, odds are they'll only be able to tell your loved ones what you died of later.

You're twitchy, shaking, and scared. You have the normal fear of not knowing what's going on, but with the virus really fucking the amygdala this is amplified a hundred fold. It's around this time the hydrophobia starts.

You're horribly thirsty, you just want water. But you can't drink. Every time you do, your throat clamps shut and you vomit. This has become a legitimate, active fear of water. You're thirsty, but looking at a glass of water begins to make you gag, and shy back in fear. The contradiction is hard for your hot brain to see at this point. By now, the doctors will have to put you on IVs to keep you hydrated, but even that's futile. You were dead the second you had a headache.

You begin hearing things, or not hearing at all as your thalamus goes. You taste sounds, you see smells, everything starts feeling like the most horrifying acid trip anyone has ever been on. With your hippocampus long under attack, you're having trouble remembering things, especially family.

You're alone, hallucinating, thirsty, confused, and absolutely, undeniably terrified. Everything scares the literal shit out of you at this point. These strange people in lab coats. These strange people standing around your bed crying, who keep trying to get you "drink something" and crying. And it's only been about a week since that little headache that you've completely forgotten. Time means nothing to you anymore. Funny enough, you now know how the bat felt when he bit you.

Eventually, you slip into the "dumb rabies" phase. Your brain has started the process of shutting down. Too much of it has been turned to liquid virus. Your face droops. You drool. You're all but unaware of what's around you. A sudden noise or light might startle you, but for the most part, it's all you can do to just stare at the ground. You haven't really slept for about 72 hours.

Then you die. Always, you die.

And there's not one... fucking... thing... anyone can do for you.

Then there's the question of what to do with your corpse. I mean, sure, burying it is the right thing to do. But the fucking virus can survive in a corpse for years. You could kill every rabid animal on the planet today, and if two years from now, some moist, preserved, rotten hunk of used-to-be brain gets eaten by an animal, it starts all over.

So yeah, rabies scares the shit out of me. And it's fucking EVERYWHERE.

A few points:
1) Up to 2004 no person had survived rabies after the onset of symptoms. However, since that time 29 people have survived through new techniques such as The Milwaukee Protocol. Still, when you consider that over 55,000 people die from rabies each year, 29 survivors in 18 years still means that rabies is almost 100% fatal after the onset of symptoms.
2) Birds have been found to carry rabies antibodies, showing that they’ve been infected. However they never become symptomatic.
3) At one point near the end, you imply (with a picture) that squirrels may be rabid. While this is possible since squirrels are mammals, it would be an extremely rare event, because any squirrel that’s bitten by a rabid animal will very likely die immediately. This is why rabies is more common in larger mammals, which can be bitten but survive long enough for the virus to incubate.

Learning exactly how the virus travels in the body is truly fascinating. In the vet tech course I took, we learned that it travelled directly through the nerves, but not in such detail. Still, it truly is one of the most terrifying diseases of all time. I remember one of the first episodes of House featured rabies and completely romanticized the virus and butchered the severity of the symptoms. I think the part that made me the most mad was that the patient was still capable of saying some final words seconds before her death. That would be impossible. With the hydrophobia, encephalitis, and probable paralysis, there would be little chance you would even still be lucid let alone able to speak. Though if you were lucid at that point, you'd wish you weren't. And if you could still speak, you'd be asking for someone to kill you.

One thing to note: infected patients develop hydrophobia (fear of water) mostly due to how drinking water will cause horrible pain even if they're severely emaciated/dehydrated. The only known treatment is an induced coma (the Milwaukee Protocol), but even that only has a 14% success rate. It's not ideal, but it's still a better chance than 0%.

I'm retired from the pharmaceutical manufacturing industry. My most recent job was at a facility that made vaccines for animals. Some of those vaccines included rabies. Our rabies vaccine was made from killed virus in another facility, but we did a small amount of testing with the live virus, so we had some in one of the research labs. About 150 of us, including me, had to get the pre-exposure rabies shots - 3 shots in 4 weeks, with a blood test before, another a few months after, then annually. If you failed the post-shot test you had to get a booster.

And still, with all those shots and all that testing, we had an agreement with a near-by hospital. If anyone at our site was exposed to live rabies virus they could get the 1st post-exposure shot in less than an hour.
Science is awesome. We take it for granted.
I’m as suspicious as one can be of the present “v@xine” of interest, but if I’m exposed to rabies I’ll gladly jab that needle into myself if I must.

After such an insightful showcase of how the rabies virus works, I was really expecting a similar walkthrough of what the vaccine does to help prepare the body to recognize and fight off such an infection.

I realize that these videos already take a tremendous amount of effort and research. And I do support vaccines from a position of genuinely wanting to improve the health and wellbeing of people. But having friends that are less than trustful of vaccines for surprisingly good reasons, or with moral qualms against their production, it doesn't really help to just say that "vaccines help". Give us more details, as much as you can! What is the vaccine really? How is it produced? What effect does it have on the body and what does a vaccinated immune system do differently?
I realize many of these could be answered with further, independent research or even through this video's sponsor, but without including it in this video makes it seem like I'm only hearing half the story. That isn't going to convince anyone.

Learning exactly how the virus travels in the body is truly fascinating. In the vet tech course I took, we learned that it travelled directly through the nerves, but not in such detail. Still, it truly is one of the most terrifying diseases of all time. I remember one of the first episodes of House featured rabies and completely romanticized the virus and butchered the severity of the symptoms. I think the part that made me the most mad was that the patient was still capable of saying some final words seconds before her death. That would be impossible. With the hydrophobia, encephalitis, and probable paralysis, there would be little chance you would even still be lucid let alone able to speak. Though if you were lucid at that point, you'd wish you weren't. And if you could still speak, you'd be asking for someone to kill you.

One thing to note: infected patients develop hydrophobia (fear of water) mostly due to how drinking water will cause horrible pain even if they're severely emaciated/dehydrated. The only known treatment is an induced coma (the Milwaukee Protocol), but even that only has a 14% success rate. It's not ideal, but it's still a better chance than 0%.

A few points:
1) Up to 2004 no person had survived rabies after the onset of symptoms. However, since that time 29 people have survived through new techniques such as The Milwaukee Protocol. Still, when you consider that over 55,000 people die from rabies each year, 29 survivors in 18 years still means that rabies is almost 100% fatal after the onset of symptoms.
2) Birds have been found to carry rabies antibodies, showing that they’ve been infected. However they never become symptomatic.
3) At one point near the end, you imply (with a picture) that squirrels may be rabid. While this is possible since squirrels are mammals, it would be an extremely rare event, because any squirrel that’s bitten by a rabid animal will very likely die immediately. This is why rabies is more common in larger mammals, which can be bitten but survive long enough for the virus to incubate.

Only 29 documented people have survived rabies. 18 of them had severe damage like complete paralysis. One of the 18 died five years later, anyway. 4 had moderate damage like partial paralysis. 3 had mild side effects likes weakness, poorer coordination, or involuntary movements. Only two made a complete recovery with no noticeable symptoms. Also, only 2 of the 29 people who recovered weren't vaccinated. Most of the 29 cases' vaccination failed. Out of the two complete recovery cases, one (17 yr old from Turkey) received one dose of a rabies vaccine post-exposure (you should get 4 doses plus immunoglobulin). The other case (6 yr old from USA) received a dose of a vaccine just two days before symptoms showed up (18 days after the bite), which is definitely too late. It's said that after 3 days, it's too late to get vaccinated and this is 6 times that, so it's unclear how much the vaccine helped. Neither of these patients were treated with the Milwaukee Protocol or Recife protocol since the American kid's case happened in 1970 (Milwaukee Protocol was first used in 2003) and the other kid's case was in Turkey in 2008, only 5 years after the Milwaukee protocol's first use in a different country. That said, it's not very common to use the Milwaukee protocol. Only 36 patients were treated with it, out which 5 survived, yielding it a 14% survival rate compared to 0% of people: 29 people including those who survived using the Milwaukee protocol out of so many people: 59,000 dead every year worldwide (that's every year, not total).

Rabies is scary.

Rabies. It's exceptionally common, but people just don't run into the animals that carry it often. Skunks especially, and bats.

Let me paint you a picture.

You go camping, and at midday you decide to take a nap in a nice little hammock. While sleeping, a tiny brown bat, in the "rage" stages of infection is fidgeting in broad daylight, uncomfortable, and thirsty (due to the hydrophobia) and you snort, startling him. He goes into attack mode.

Except you're asleep, and he's a little brown bat, so weighs around 6 grams. You don't even feel him land on your bare knee, and he starts to bite. His teeth are tiny. Hardly enough to even break the skin, but he does manage to give you the equivalent of a tiny scrape that goes completely unnoticed.

Rabies does not travel in your blood. In fact, a blood test won't even tell you if you've got it. (Antibody tests may be done, but are useless if you've ever been vaccinated.)

You wake up, none the wiser. If you notice anything at the bite site at all, you assume you just lightly scraped it on something.

The bomb has been lit, and your nervous system is the wick. The rabies will multiply along your nervous system, doing virtually no damage, and completely undetectable. You literally have NO symptoms.

It may be four days, it may be a year, but the camping trip is most likely long forgotten. Then one day your back starts to ache... Or maybe you get a slight headache?

At this point, you're already dead. There is no cure.

(The sole caveat to this is the Milwaukee Protocol, which leaves most patients dead anyway, and the survivors mentally disabled, and is seldom done).

There's no treatment. It has a 100% kill rate.

Absorb that. Not a single other virus on the planet has a 100% kill rate. Only rabies. And once you're symptomatic, it's over. You're dead.

So what does that look like?

Your headache turns into a fever, and a general feeling of being unwell. You're fidgety. Uncomfortable. And scared. As the virus that has taken its time getting into your brain finds a vast network of nerve endings, it begins to rapidly reproduce, starting at the base of your brain... Where your "pons" is located. This is the part of the brain that controls communication between the rest of the brain and body, as well as sleep cycles.

Next you become anxious. You still think you have only a mild fever, but suddenly you find yourself becoming scared, even horrified, and it doesn't occur to you that you don't know why. This is because the rabies is chewing up your amygdala.

As your cerebellum becomes hot with the virus, you begin to lose muscle coordination, and balance. You think maybe it's a good idea to go to the doctor now, but assuming a doctor is smart enough to even run the tests necessary in the few days you have left on the planet, odds are they'll only be able to tell your loved ones what you died of later.

You're twitchy, shaking, and scared. You have the normal fear of not knowing what's going on, but with the virus really fucking the amygdala this is amplified a hundred fold. It's around this time the hydrophobia starts.

You're horribly thirsty, you just want water. But you can't drink. Every time you do, your throat clamps shut and you vomit. This has become a legitimate, active fear of water. You're thirsty, but looking at a glass of water begins to make you gag, and shy back in fear. The contradiction is hard for your hot brain to see at this point. By now, the doctors will have to put you on IVs to keep you hydrated, but even that's futile. You were dead the second you had a headache.

You begin hearing things, or not hearing at all as your thalamus goes. You taste sounds, you see smells, everything starts feeling like the most horrifying acid trip anyone has ever been on. With your hippocampus long under attack, you're having trouble remembering things, especially family.

You're alone, hallucinating, thirsty, confused, and absolutely, undeniably terrified. Everything scares the literal shit out of you at this point. These strange people in lab coats. These strange people standing around your bed crying, who keep trying to get you "drink something" and crying. And it's only been about a week since that little headache that you've completely forgotten. Time means nothing to you anymore. Funny enough, you now know how the bat felt when he bit you.

Eventually, you slip into the "dumb rabies" phase. Your brain has started the process of shutting down. Too much of it has been turned to liquid virus. Your face droops. You drool. You're all but unaware of what's around you. A sudden noise or light might startle you, but for the most part, it's all you can do to just stare at the ground. You haven't really slept for about 72 hours.

Then you die. Always, you die.

And there's not one... fucking... thing... anyone can do for you.

Then there's the question of what to do with your corpse. I mean, sure, burying it is the right thing to do. But the fucking virus can survive in a corpse for years. You could kill every rabid animal on the planet today, and if two years from now, some moist, preserved, rotten hunk of used-to-be brain gets eaten by an animal, it starts all over.

So yeah, rabies scares the shit out of me. And it's fucking EVERYWHERE. (Source: Spent a lot of time working with rabies. Would still get my vaccinations if I could afford them.)

When people said “100% lethal”, that was not a game rule ( if “exposure to rabies” then “life = -1” ) , it was just a conclusion based on uncontrolled observations over the years, without strict controls. And that 100% lethality is based on “AFTER neurological symptoms start” which means way after infection, and infection is way after exposure.

The point being that while rabies has extremely high mortality, it is definitely not 100%, and when the rare individual survives, that survival should not be assumed to be some kind of erroneous documentation or result of freak mutation that violates a rule.

There is no categorical reason for rabies to have a mechanism that’s 100% lethal (like having your body placed under water for 12 days). It’s still a virus, with resulting mechanisms that produce extremely high fevers and bad cerebral edema.

One of the main reasons for the near 100% lethality after symptoms start, is that by that point, you already have a infection all over the brain. Same reason that naegleria (brain amoeba) or massive radiation exposure is nearly 100% fatal. By the time you have an actual symptom, most people have already taken lethal damage.

I feel the need to clarify something that this video does not clarify: in the United States, if you are a member of the general public, you are NOT eligible for pre-exposure vaccination. Post-exposure prophylaxis (getting a series of rabies shots after being bitten or scratched by a suspected infected animal) is the only option for the general public. Pretty much the only people eligible for pre-exposure vaccination are those who work in animal control, and they still have to receive post-exposure prophylaxis after being bitten or scratched. Pre-exposure vaccination isn’t necessary for the general public because human-to-human transmission has never been recorded. That’s why we vaccinate our pets! Animal-to-animal and animal-to-human transmission are how this virus spreads.

All of that being said, I think it’s irresponsible to imply that general skepticism of some vaccines equates to an increase in rabies cases. I support some vaccines (smallpox, MMR) but not all (Covid, Flu). I don’t know any universal anti-vaxxers, so I don’t know what their opinion of post-exposure rabies treatment is, but I do think it’s unfair to conflate my skepticism of vaccines like Covid and Flu with opposition to literally the only effective treatment for rabies exposure 😅

Rabies. It's exceptionally common, but people just don't run into the animals that carry it often. Skunks especially, and bats.
Let me paint you a picture.
You go camping, and at midday you decide to take a nap in a nice little hammock. While sleeping, a tiny brown bat, in the "rage" stages of infection is fidgeting in broad daylight, uncomfortable, and thirsty (due to the hydrophobia) and you snort, startling him. He goes into attack mode.
Except you're asleep, and he's a little brown bat, so weighs around 6 grams. You don't even feel him land on your bare knee, and he starts to bite. His teeth are tiny. Hardly enough to even break the skin, but he does manage to give you the equivalent of a tiny scrape that goes completely unnoticed.
Rabies does not travel in your blood. In fact, a blood test won't even tell you if you've got it. (Antibody tests may be done, but are useless if you've ever been vaccinated.)
You wake up, none the wiser. If you notice anything at the bite site at all, you assume you just lightly scraped it on something.
The bomb has been lit, and your nervous system is the wick. The rabies will multiply along your nervous system, doing virtually no damage, and completely undetectable. You literally have NO symptoms.
It may be four days, it may be a year, but the camping trip is most likely long forgotten. Then one day your back starts to ache... Or maybe you get a slight headache?
At this point, you're already dead. There is no cure.
(The sole caveat to this is the Milwaukee Protocol, which leaves most patients dead anyway, and the survivors mentally disabled, and is seldom done).
There's no treatment. It has a 100% kill rate.
Absorb that. Not a single other virus on the planet has a 100% kill rate. Only rabies. And once you're symptomatic, it's over. You're dead.
So what does that look like?
Your headache turns into a fever, and a general feeling of being unwell. You're fidgety. Uncomfortable. And scared. As the virus that has taken its time getting into your brain finds a vast network of nerve endings, it begins to rapidly reproduce, starting at the base of your brain... Where your "pons" is located. This is the part of the brain that controls communication between the rest of the brain and body, as well as sleep cycles.
Next you become anxious. You still think you have only a mild fever, but suddenly you find yourself becoming scared, even horrified, and it doesn't occur to you that you don't know why. This is because the rabies is chewing up your amygdala.
As your cerebellum becomes hot with the virus, you begin to lose muscle coordination, and balance. You think maybe it's a good idea to go to the doctor now, but assuming a doctor is smart enough to even run the tests necessary in the few days you have left on the planet, odds are they'll only be able to tell your loved ones what you died of later.
You're twitchy, shaking, and scared. You have the normal fear of not knowing what's going on, but with the virus really fucking the amygdala this is amplified a hundred fold. It's around this time the hydrophobia starts.
You're horribly thirsty, you just want water. But you can't drink. Every time you do, your throat clamps shut and you vomit. This has become a legitimate, active fear of water. You're thirsty, but looking at a glass of water begins to make you gag, and shy back in fear. The contradiction is hard for your hot brain to see at this point. By now, the doctors will have to put you on IVs to keep you hydrated, but even that's futile. You were dead the second you had a headache.
You begin hearing things, or not hearing at all as your thalamus goes. You taste sounds, you see smells, everything starts feeling like the most horrifying acid trip anyone has ever been on. With your hippocampus long under attack, you're having trouble remembering things, especially family.
You're alone, hallucinating, thirsty, confused, and absolutely, undeniably terrified. Everything scares the literal shit out of you at this point. These strange people in lab coats. These strange people standing around your bed crying, who keep trying to get you "drink something" and crying. And it's only been about a week since that little headache that you've completely forgotten. Time means nothing to you anymore. Funny enough, you now know how the bat felt when he bit you.
Eventually, you slip into the "dumb rabies" phase. Your brain has started the process of shutting down. Too much of it has been turned to liquid virus. Your face droops. You drool. You're all but unaware of what's around you. A sudden noise or light might startle you, but for the most part, it's all you can do to just stare at the ground. You haven't really slept for about 72 hours.
Then you die. Always, you die.
And there's not one... fucking... thing... anyone can do for you.
Then there's the question of what to do with your corpse. I mean, sure, burying it is the right thing to do. But the fucking virus can survive in a corpse for years. You could kill every rabid animal on the planet today, and if two years from now, some moist, preserved, rotten hunk of used-to-be brain gets eaten by an animal, it starts all over.
So yeah, rabies scares the shit out of me. And it's fucking EVERYWHERE. (Source: Spent a lot of time working with rabies. Would still get my vaccinations if I could afford them.)

Rabies. It's exceptionally common, but people just don't run into the animals that carry it often. Skunks especially, and bats.

Let me paint you a picture.

You go camping, and at midday you decide to take a nap in a nice little hammock. While sleeping, a tiny brown bat, in the "rage" stages of infection is fidgeting in broad daylight, uncomfortable, and thirsty (due to the hydrophobia) and you snort, startling him. He goes into attack mode.

Except you're asleep, and he's a little brown bat, so weighs around 6 grams. You don't even feel him land on your bare knee, and he starts to bite. His teeth are tiny. Hardly enough to even break the skin, but he does manage to give you the equivalent of a tiny scrape that goes completely unnoticed.

Rabies does not travel in your blood. In fact, a blood test won't even tell you if you've got it. (Antibody tests may be done, but are useless if you've ever been vaccinated.)

You wake up, none the wiser. If you notice anything at the bite site at all, you assume you just lightly scraped it on something.

The bomb has been lit, and your nervous system is the wick. The rabies will multiply along your nervous system, doing virtually no damage, and completely undetectable. You literally have NO symptoms.

It may be four days, it may be a year, but the camping trip is most likely long forgotten. Then one day your back starts to ache... Or maybe you get a slight headache?

At this point, you're already dead. There is no cure.

(The sole caveat to this is the Milwaukee Protocol, which leaves most patients dead anyway, and the survivors mentally disabled, and is seldom done).

There's no treatment. It has a 100% kill rate.

Absorb that. Not a single other virus on the planet has a 100% kill rate. Only rabies. And once you're symptomatic, it's over. You're dead.

So what does that look like?

Your headache turns into a fever, and a general feeling of being unwell. You're fidgety. Uncomfortable. And scared. As the virus that has taken its time getting into your brain finds a vast network of nerve endings, it begins to rapidly reproduce, starting at the base of your brain... Where your "pons" is located. This is the part of the brain that controls communication between the rest of the brain and body, as well as sleep cycles.

Next you become anxious. You still think you have only a mild fever, but suddenly you find yourself becoming scared, even horrified, and it doesn't occur to you that you don't know why. This is because the rabies is chewing up your amygdala.

As your cerebellum becomes hot with the virus, you begin to lose muscle coordination, and balance. You think maybe it's a good idea to go to the doctor now, but assuming a doctor is smart enough to even run the tests necessary in the few days you have left on the planet, odds are they'll only be able to tell your loved ones what you died of later.

You're twitchy, shaking, and scared. You have the normal fear of not knowing what's going on, but with the virus really fucking the amygdala this is amplified a hundred fold. It's around this time the hydrophobia starts.

You're horribly thirsty, you just want water. But you can't drink. Every time you do, your throat clamps shut and you vomit. This has become a legitimate, active fear of water. You're thirsty, but looking at a glass of water begins to make you gag, and shy back in fear. The contradiction is hard for your hot brain to see at this point. By now, the doctors will have to put you on IVs to keep you hydrated, but even that's futile. You were dead the second you had a headache.

You begin hearing things, or not hearing at all as your thalamus goes. You taste sounds, you see smells, everything starts feeling like the most horrifying acid trip anyone has ever been on. With your hippocampus long under attack, you're having trouble remembering things, especially family.

You're alone, hallucinating, thirsty, confused, and absolutely, undeniably terrified. Everything scares the literal shit out of you at this point. These strange people in lab coats. These strange people standing around your bed crying, who keep trying to get you "drink something" and crying. And it's only been about a week since that little headache that you've completely forgotten. Time means nothing to you anymore. Funny enough, you now know how the bat felt when he bit you.

Eventually, you slip into the "dumb rabies" phase. Your brain has started the process of shutting down. Too much of it has been turned to liquid virus. Your face droops. You drool. You're all but unaware of what's around you. A sudden noise or light might startle you, but for the most part, it's all you can do to just stare at the ground. You haven't really slept for about 72 hours.

Then you die. Always, you die.

And there's not one... fucking... thing... anyone can do for you.

Then there's the question of what to do with your corpse. I mean, sure, burying it is the right thing to do. But the fucking virus can survive in a corpse for years. You could kill every rabid animal on the planet today, and if two years from now, some moist, preserved, rotten hunk of used-to-be brain gets eaten by an animal, it starts all over.

So yeah, rabies scares the shit out of me. And it's fucking EVERYWHERE. (Source: Spent a lot of time working with rabies. Would still get my vaccinations if I could afford them.)

Minor but important correction. Probably because you're not native English speakers.

"Viruses exist on the edge between life and death"

Not true. A more accurate statement would be "Viruses exist on the edge between life and non-life". For something to die, it had to have been alive. Viruses don't fit all the requirements we believe must be true of all living beings (for example, they don't expend energy, for starters). Hence, they're on the edge between "living and non-living", not "life and death".

So rabies infected humans become violent and dangerous, but generally don't spread the virus by biting simply because humans don't bite even during violent acts.

Great video as always, but I feel that it barely touches what IMO is the most interesting thing about this virus - that it appears to use psychological manipulation of its victim as a key step in it's life cycle. Few, if any viruses do this and it's almost a complete mystery how this works.

The brain infection is not random, the virus very particularly seems to impact the brain to cause its victims to develop hydrophobia and aggression.

The hydrophobia is related to the severe salivation, and the aggression causes otherwise docile animals to become very bitey, both critical elements for transmitting the virus.

I find the idea that a virus can target our psychology and/or somehow rewire our brains to modify our behavior both fascinating and deeply disturbing.

Is it possible for virus to modify a human body, to spread easier without major harm to the host?

Rabies. It's exceptionally common, but people just don't run into the animals that carry it often. Skunks especially, and bats.

Let me paint you a picture.

You go camping, and at midday you decide to take a nap in a nice little hammock. While sleeping, a tiny brown bat, in the "rage" stages of infection is fidgeting in broad daylight, uncomfortable, and thirsty (due to the hydrophobia) and you snort, startling him. He goes into attack mode.

Except you're asleep, and he's a little brown bat, so weighs around 6 grams. You don't even feel him land on your bare knee, and he starts to bite. His teeth are tiny. Hardly enough to even break the skin, but he does manage to give you the equivalent of a tiny scrape that goes completely unnoticed.

Rabies does not travel in your blood. In fact, a blood test won't even tell you if you've got it. (Antibody tests may be done, but are useless if you've ever been vaccinated.)

You wake up, none the wiser. If you notice anything at the bite site at all, you assume you just lightly scraped it on something.

The bomb has been lit, and your nervous system is the wick. The rabies will multiply along your nervous system, doing virtually no damage, and completely undetectable. You literally have NO symptoms.

It may be four days, it may be a year, but the camping trip is most likely long forgotten. Then one day your back starts to ache... Or maybe you get a slight headache?

At this point, you're already dead. There is no cure.

(The sole caveat to this is the Milwaukee Protocol, which leaves most patients dead anyway, and the survivors mentally disabled, and is seldom done).

There's no treatment. It has a 100% kill rate.

Absorb that. Not a single other virus on the planet has a 100% kill rate. Only rabies. And once you're symptomatic, it's over. You're dead.

So what does that look like?

Your headache turns into a fever, and a general feeling of being unwell. You're fidgety. Uncomfortable. And scared. As the virus that has taken its time getting into your brain finds a vast network of nerve endings, it begins to rapidly reproduce, starting at the base of your brain... Where your "pons" is located. This is the part of the brain that controls communication between the rest of the brain and body, as well as sleep cycles.

Next you become anxious. You still think you have only a mild fever, but suddenly you find yourself becoming scared, even horrified, and it doesn't occur to you that you don't know why. This is because the rabies is chewing up your amygdala.

As your cerebellum becomes hot with the virus, you begin to lose muscle coordination, and balance. You think maybe it's a good idea to go to the doctor now, but assuming a doctor is smart enough to even run the tests necessary in the few days you have left on the planet, odds are they'll only be able to tell your loved ones what you died of later.

You're twitchy, shaking, and scared. You have the normal fear of not knowing what's going on, but with the virus really fucking the amygdala this is amplified a hundred fold. It's around this time the hydrophobia starts.

You're horribly thirsty, you just want water. But you can't drink. Every time you do, your throat clamps shut and you vomit. This has become a legitimate, active fear of water. You're thirsty, but looking at a glass of water begins to make you gag, and shy back in fear. The contradiction is hard for your hot brain to see at this point. By now, the doctors will have to put you on IVs to keep you hydrated, but even that's futile. You were dead the second you had a headache.

You begin hearing things, or not hearing at all as your thalamus goes. You taste sounds, you see smells, everything starts feeling like the most horrifying acid trip anyone has ever been on. With your hippocampus long under attack, you're having trouble remembering things, especially family.

You're alone, hallucinating, thirsty, confused, and absolutely, undeniably terrified. Everything scares the literal shit out of you at this point. These strange people in lab coats. These strange people standing around your bed crying, who keep trying to get you "drink something" and crying. And it's only been about a week since that little headache that you've completely forgotten. Time means nothing to you anymore. Funny enough, you now know how the bat felt when he bit you.

Eventually, you slip into the "dumb rabies" phase. Your brain has started the process of shutting down. Too much of it has been turned to liquid virus. Your face droops. You drool. You're all but unaware of what's around you. A sudden noise or light might startle you, but for the most part, it's all you can do to just stare at the ground. You haven't really slept for about 72 hours.

Then you die. Always, you die.

And there's not one... fucking... thing... anyone can do for you.

Then there's the question of what to do with your corpse. I mean, sure, burying it is the right thing to do. But the fucking virus can survive in a corpse for years. You could kill every rabid animal on the planet today, and if two years from now, some moist, preserved, rotten hunk of used-to-be brain gets eaten by an animal, it starts all over.

So yeah, rabies scares the shit out of me. And it's fucking EVERYWHERE.

Not sure if this video is getting across just how incredibly dangerous rabies is. Once you start showing symptoms, you are dead. It doesn't matter what treatments you get, if you don't the vaccine in time, you will die a very bad death.
The 'Milwaukee' protocol (if it actually works, there is debate) has saved less than two dozen people. In all of human history, less than two dozen people have survived rabies. And those people do not come out of the coma the same.
By sheer statistical numbers, there are probably people out there that are immune to rabies. But it is so dangerous, no one is volunteering to get bitten by a rabid dog any time soon.

A lot of people think that rabies is commonly spread through rats and squirrels, but this is untrue. I'll be sharing my favorite copypasta of this virus.

Rabies.
It's exceptionally common, but people just don't run into the animals that carry it often. Skunks especially, and bats.

Let me paint you a picture.

You go camping, and at midday you decide to take a nap in a nice little hammock. While sleeping, a tiny brown bat, in the "rage" stages of infection is fidgeting in broad daylight, uncomfortable, and thirsty (due to the hydrophobia) and you snort, startling him. He goes into attack mode.

Except you're asleep, and he's a little brown bat, so weighs around 6 grams. You don't even feel him land on your bare knee, and he starts to bite. His teeth are tiny. Hardly enough to even break the skin, but he does manage to give you the equivalent of a tiny scrape that goes completely unnoticed.

Rabies does not travel in your blood. In fact, a blood test won't even tell you if you've got it. (Antibody tests may be done, but are useless if you've ever been vaccinated.)

You wake up, none the wiser. If you notice anything at the bite site at all, you assume you just lightly scraped it on something.

The bomb has been lit, and your nervous system is the wick. The rabies will multiply along your nervous system, doing virtually no damage, and completely undetectable. You literally have NO symptoms.

It may be four days, it may be a year, but the camping trip is most likely long forgotten. Then one day your back starts to ache... Or maybe you get a slight headache?

At this point, you're already dead. There is no cure.

(The sole caveat to this is the Milwaukee Protocol, which leaves most patients dead anyway, and the survivors mentally disabled, and is seldom done).

There's no treatment. It has a 100% kill rate.

Absorb that. Not a single other virus on the planet has a 100% kill rate. Only rabies. And once you're symptomatic, it's over. You're dead.

So what does that look like?

Your headache turns into a fever, and a general feeling of being unwell. You're fidgety. Uncomfortable. And scared. As the virus that has taken its time getting into your brain finds a vast network of nerve endings, it begins to rapidly reproduce, starting at the base of your brain... Where your "pons" is located. This is the part of the brain that controls communication between the rest of the brain and body, as well as sleep cycles.

Next you become anxious. You still think you have only a mild fever, but suddenly you find yourself becoming scared, even horrified, and it doesn't occur to you that you don't know why. This is because the rabies is chewing up your amygdala.

As your cerebellum becomes hot with the virus, you begin to lose muscle coordination, and balance. You think maybe it's a good idea to go to the doctor now, but assuming a doctor is smart enough to even run the tests necessary in the few days you have left on the planet, odds are they'll only be able to tell your loved ones what you died of later.

You're twitchy, shaking, and scared. You have the normal fear of not knowing what's going on, but with the virus really fucking the amygdala this is amplified a hundred fold. It's around this time the hydrophobia starts.

You're horribly thirsty, you just want water. But you can't drink. Every time you do, your throat clamps shut and you vomit. This has become a legitimate, active fear of water. You're thirsty, but looking at a glass of water begins to make you gag, and shy back in fear. The contradiction is hard for your hot brain to see at this point. By now, the doctors will have to put you on IVs to keep you hydrated, but even that's futile. You were dead the second you had a headache.

You begin hearing things, or not hearing at all as your thalamus goes. You taste sounds, you see smells, everything starts feeling like the most horrifying acid trip anyone has ever been on. With your hippocampus long under attack, you're having trouble remembering things, especially family.

You're alone, hallucinating, thirsty, confused, and absolutely, undeniably terrified. Everything scares the literal shit out of you at this point. These strange people in lab coats. These strange people standing around your bed crying, who keep trying to get you "drink something" and crying. And it's only been about a week since that little headache that you've completely forgotten. Time means nothing to you anymore. Funny enough, you now know how the bat felt when he bit you.

Eventually, you slip into the "dumb rabies" phase. Your brain has started the process of shutting down. Too much of it has been turned to liquid virus. Your face droops. You drool. You're all but unaware of what's around you. A sudden noise or light might startle you, but for the most part, it's all you can do to just stare at the ground. You haven't really slept for about 72 hours.

Then you die. Always, you die.

And there's not one... fucking... thing... anyone can do for you.

Then there's the question of what to do with your corpse. I mean, sure, burying it is the right thing to do. But the fucking virus can survive in a corpse for years. You could kill every rabid animal on the planet today, and if two years from now, some moist, preserved, rotten hunk of used-to-be brain gets eaten by an animal, it starts all over.

So yeah, rabies scares the shit out of me. And it's fucking EVERYWHERE

"In conclusion, according to the available evidence, Israelite religion in its earliest form did not contrast markedly with the religions of its Levantine neighbors in either number or configuration of deities. Rather, the number of
deities in Israel was relatively typical for the region. Furthermore, as they did in the religions of surrounding states, some old Canaanite deities continued within an Israelite pantheon dominated by a national god. Like some of the Phoenician city-states and perhaps Edom, earliest Israel knew El, Baal, a new dynastic or national god, the divine council, a partial divinization of deceased
ancestors (Rephaim), and perhaps the cult of a goddess. Similarly, during the period of the Judges, Yahweh held hegemony over a complex religion that preserved some old Canaanite components through an identification with El,
a continuation of the concepts of the divine council and partially divinized ancestors, a coexistence with Baal, and perhaps an early toleration for Asherah and subsequent assimilation of her cult and symbol, the asherah.

The virus accumulates in saliva so it makes you terrified even if you look at water. Because if you drink water it gets less concentrated and thus less likely to be transmitted. Or at least that's how I think it works.

One day there were people vaccinating dogs against rabies in my neighbourhood, and when they came to my house I thought it would be nice to have my dog vaccinated. My dog got vaccinated in the morning around 11 am, everything seemed fine until later in the afternoon I noticed my dog's mood was a bit down, I told myself maybe he's bored...then around 7 pm he alarmed everyone in the house when he started to cry and run around. He cried very loudly as if it had intense pain inside, my dad and I tried to calm it down but our efforts were in vain, the dog kept running and crying until suddenly it fell paralyzed. At this moment it was very clear that the vaccine was the cause of that behaviour. Shortly after my dog woke up and ran inside the bathroom. We locked the door to prevent him from running around all the house again and because we were worried he might bite someone. After some minutes I went to see how he was as he seemed to have calmed down (I had the hope that he would recover since "the worst already happened"). There he was lying on the floor and foaming in the mouth, I kneeled down to keep him company, I was dubious at first but he never showed "rage" during all this time. He definitely showed fear and pain though, but now he was without strength, probably unable to move. He died around 8 pm.
Can you imagine the guilt and anger I felt with myself (and the guys that vaccinated him) after basically killing my own dog. Maybe he was too young or maybe the dose was too strong, maybe both, who knows. But yeah my dog had a bad experience with that vaccine. Thankfully he never turned against me or my family and showed fear instead of rage. If he had bitten me when I tried to hold him and calm him down maybe I would not be writing this now.
I have two dogs now but after what happened to my previous one I'd rather just hope they never get infected with rabies in the first place than contemplating the possibility of reliving that experience.
Life sucks harder when you try to do some good and it ends up being bad.

So I gotta make the obligatory copy pasta to scare people a little bit more about rabies

Rabies. It's exceptionally common, but people just don't run into the animals that carry it often. Skunks especially, and bats.

Let me paint you a picture.

You go camping, and at midday you decide to take a nap in a nice little hammock. While sleeping, a tiny brown bat, in the "rage" stages of infection is fidgeting in broad daylight, uncomfortable, and thirsty (due to the hydrophobia) and you snort, startling him. He goes into attack mode.

Except you're asleep, and he's a little brown bat, so weighs around 6 grams. You don't even feel him land on your bare knee, and he starts to bite. His teeth are tiny. Hardly enough to even break the skin, but he does manage to give you the equivalent of a tiny scrape that goes completely unnoticed.

Rabies does not travel in your blood. In fact, a blood test won't even tell you if you've got it. (Antibody tests may be done, but are useless if you've ever been vaccinated.)

You wake up, none the wiser. If you notice anything at the bite site at all, you assume you just lightly scraped it on something.

The bomb has been lit, and your nervous system is the wick. The rabies will multiply along your nervous system, doing virtually no damage, and completely undetectable. You literally have NO symptoms.

It may be four days, it may be a year, but the camping trip is most likely long forgotten. Then one day your back starts to ache... Or maybe you get a slight headache?

At this point, you're already dead. There is no cure.

(The sole caveat to this is the Milwaukee Protocol, which leaves most patients dead anyway, and the survivors mentally disabled, and is seldom done).

There's no treatment. It has a 100% kill rate.

Absorb that. Not a single other virus on the planet has a 100% kill rate. Only rabies. And once you're symptomatic, it's over. You're dead.

So what does that look like?

Your headache turns into a fever, and a general feeling of being unwell. You're fidgety. Uncomfortable. And scared. As the virus that has taken its time getting into your brain finds a vast network of nerve endings, it begins to rapidly reproduce, starting at the base of your brain... Where your "pons" is located. This is the part of the brain that controls communication between the rest of the brain and body, as well as sleep cycles.

Next you become anxious. You still think you have only a mild fever, but suddenly you find yourself becoming scared, even horrified, and it doesn't occur to you that you don't know why. This is because the rabies is chewing up your amygdala.

As your cerebellum becomes hot with the virus, you begin to lose muscle coordination, and balance. You think maybe it's a good idea to go to the doctor now, but assuming a doctor is smart enough to even run the tests necessary in the few days you have left on the planet, odds are they'll only be able to tell your loved ones what you died of later.

You're twitchy, shaking, and scared. You have the normal fear of not knowing what's going on, but with the virus really fucking the amygdala this is amplified a hundred fold. It's around this time the hydrophobia starts.

You're horribly thirsty, you just want water. But you can't drink. Every time you do, your throat clamps shut and you vomit. This has become a legitimate, active fear of water. You're thirsty, but looking at a glass of water begins to make you gag, and shy back in fear. The contradiction is hard for your hot brain to see at this point. By now, the doctors will have to put you on IVs to keep you hydrated, but even that's futile. You were dead the second you had a headache.

You begin hearing things, or not hearing at all as your thalamus goes. You taste sounds, you see smells, everything starts feeling like the most horrifying acid trip anyone has ever been on. With your hippocampus long under attack, you're having trouble remembering things, especially family.

You're alone, hallucinating, thirsty, confused, and absolutely, undeniably terrified. Everything scares the literal shit out of you at this point. These strange people in lab coats. These strange people standing around your bed crying, who keep trying to get you "drink something" and crying. And it's only been about a week since that little headache that you've completely forgotten. Time means nothing to you anymore. Funny enough, you now know how the bat felt when he bit you.

Eventually, you slip into the "dumb rabies" phase. Your brain has started the process of shutting down. Too much of it has been turned to liquid virus. Your face droops. You drool. You're all but unaware of what's around you. A sudden noise or light might startle you, but for the most part, it's all you can do to just stare at the ground. You haven't really slept for about 72 hours.

Then you die. Always, you die.

And there's not one... fucking... thing... anyone can do for you.

Then there's the question of what to do with your corpse. I mean, sure, burying it is the right thing to do. But the fucking virus can survive in a corpse for years. You could kill every rabid animal on the planet today, and if two years from now, some moist, preserved, rotten hunk of used-to-be brain gets eaten by an animal, it starts all over.

So yeah, rabies scares the shit out of me. And it's fucking EVERYWHERE. (Source: Spent a lot of time working with rabies. Would still get my vaccinations if I could afford them.)

Note that rabies is also an example of why animal welfare is important for public health for both humans and other animals alike. Rabies in humans is common in geographical areas where animal welfare is poor and veterinary care - especially for companion animal species - is limited and even totally absent. In Southern China where there are outbreaks of rabies that affect humans nearly every year, local governments tried trap-kill programs to kill stray dogs and cats to control the spread, but they worked poorly. You can never eradicate stray dogs and cats population by killing them, because they always bounce back as long as one pair of them survive. The solution that works is TNR programs and vaccination through feeding, the ones that can improve animal welfare.

I've always found it hard to explain MHC class proteins so being able to display it is quite useful. I know it doesn't cover the class II's but I always find it incredibly useful to show these videos to people as my drawing ability is so horrible that I tend to mess up too much to get the point across. (also the motor proteins are borderline impossible to properly explain so that incredible drawing will help too)

On a completely separate note, I find it intriguing that rabies maintains a lysogenic stage even while active, conventional knowledge is that if a virus is active it is always chewing through cells as well as creating plenty of MHCI markers so it is always impressive to find an exception to the rule. It also is puzzling to me as to how an infection that does not destroy a cell still ends up killing or at least disabling it. Perhaps the viral proteins simply oversaturate protein production making it impossible for crucial proteins to be made meaning it would simply disable the neurons rather than killing them.

Rabies is more of a nuisance than a deadly plague. The number of people who get bitten during an outbreak in an industrialised country is very small, and as you say, the vaccine will protect them provided they have it soon after being bitten. In UK we have an urban fox population, and a rabid fox is more likely to bite a cat or dog than to bite a human, so in an outbreak we would sometimes be worried that our pets are infected. Very few people would die, perhaps none at all, but it would be very worrying. Badgers might also become infected. UK is free of it at present, but it is only a matter of time before we have an outbreak, maybe 50 years down the line. Urban foxes and other wildlife would have to be shot and pets quarantined.

1:20, The primary transmission vector where I grew up, in the state of Maryland, USA, was raccoons, not dogs. We were constantly being told/warned/terrified into being aware of any raccoons that were out during the day, as they are mostly nocturnal...although they Do come out in the daytime for the rare opportunity to eat an unusual treat or play with a new shiny object; and they start their food hunting during twilight, before it becomes completely dark. So, yeah; There were countless false reports about rabid raccoons being Everywhere. From the way of things, it was easy to believe that stepping outside just for a moment, to call the family cat or dog, or do anything, really, was pretty much a guarantee of being bitten by a swarm of crazed raccoons, and then slowly and painfully turned into a rabid, hybrid, zombie raccoon person, like in a real life Stephen King book. At least it was if you were seven years old...

This is why I'm always leery of those YT videos of people letting themselves and even kids get up close and intimate with "friendly" animals that they don't know. Often a wild animal that has lost it's instinctive caution of humans is actually infected with something or other. Not always but why risk it for the sake of some footage to upload online?

Rabies. It's exceptionally common, but people just don't run into the animals that carry it often. Skunks especially, and bats.

Let me paint you a picture.

You go camping, and at midday you decide to take a nap in a nice little hammock. While sleeping, a tiny brown bat, in the "rage" stages of infection is fidgeting in broad daylight, uncomfortable, and thirsty (due to the hydrophobia) and you snort, startling him. He goes into attack mode.

Except you're asleep, and he's a little brown bat, so weighs around 6 grams. You don't even feel him land on your bare knee, and he starts to bite. His teeth are tiny. Hardly enough to even break the skin, but he does manage to give you the equivalent of a tiny scrape that goes completely unnoticed.

Rabies does not travel in your blood. In fact, a blood test won't even tell you if you've got it. (Antibody tests may be done, but are useless if you've ever been vaccinated.)

You wake up, none the wiser. If you notice anything at the bite site at all, you assume you just lightly scraped it on something.

The bomb has been lit, and your nervous system is the wick. The rabies will multiply along your nervous system, doing virtually no damage, and completely undetectable. You literally have NO symptoms.

It may be four days, it may be a year, but the camping trip is most likely long forgotten. Then one day your back starts to ache... Or maybe you get a slight headache?

At this point, you're already dead. There is no cure.

There's no treatment. It has a 100% kill rate.

Absorb that. Not a single other virus on the planet has a 100% kill rate. Only rabies. And once you're symptomatic, it's over. You're dead.

So what does that look like?

Your headache turns into a fever, and a general feeling of being unwell. You're fidgety. Uncomfortable. And scared. As the virus that has taken its time getting into your brain finds a vast network of nerve endings, it begins to rapidly reproduce, starting at the base of your brain... Where your "pons" is located. This is the part of the brain that controls communication between the rest of the brain and body, as well as sleep cycles.

Next you become anxious. You still think you have only a mild fever, but suddenly you find yourself becoming scared, even horrified, and it doesn't occur to you that you don't know why. This is because the rabies is chewing up your amygdala.

As your cerebellum becomes hot with the virus, you begin to lose muscle coordination, and balance. You think maybe it's a good idea to go to the doctor now, but assuming a doctor is smart enough to even run the tests necessary in the few days you have left on the planet, odds are they'll only be able to tell your loved ones what you died of later.

You're twitchy, shaking, and scared. You have the normal fear of not knowing what's going on, but with the virus really fucking the amygdala this is amplified a hundred fold. It's around this time the hydrophobia starts.

You're horribly thirsty, you just want water. But you can't drink. Every time you do, your throat clamps shut and you vomit. This has become a legitimate, active fear of water. You're thirsty, but looking at a glass of water begins to make you gag, and shy back in fear. The contradiction is hard for your hot brain to see at this point. By now, the doctors will have to put you on IVs to keep you hydrated, but even that's futile. You were dead the second you had a headache.

You begin hearing things, or not hearing at all as your thalamus goes. You taste sounds, you see smells, everything starts feeling like the most horrifying acid trip anyone has ever been on. With your hippocampus long under attack, you're having trouble remembering things, especially family.

You're alone, hallucinating, thirsty, confused, and absolutely, undeniably terrified. Everything scares the literal shit out of you at this point. These strange people in lab coats. These strange people standing around your bed crying, who keep trying to get you "drink something" and crying. And it's only been about a week since that little headache that you've completely forgotten. Time means nothing to you anymore. Funny enough, you now know how the bat felt when he bit you.

Eventually, you slip into the "dumb rabies" phase. Your brain has started the process of shutting down. Too much of it has been turned to liquid virus. Your face droops. You drool. You're all but unaware of what's around you. A sudden noise or light might startle you, but for the most part, it's all you can do to just stare at the ground. You haven't really slept for about 72 hours.

Then you die. Always, you die.

And there's not one... fucking... thing... anyone can do for you.

Then there's the question of what to do with your corpse. I mean, sure, burying it is the right thing to do. But the fucking virus can survive in a corpse for years. You could kill every rabid animal on the planet today, and if two years from now, some moist, preserved, rotten hunk of used-to-be brain gets eaten by an animal, it starts all over.

So yeah, rabies scares the shit out of me. And it's fucking EVERYWHERE.

Suspicion about vaccines are okay. Understanding that vaccines as described, are good is what's important.
The definition being, a small dose of a disease is administered to your body so that it can learn to fight it and develop what is needed for it. Unless a disease changes, in the case of the flu. The reason for people being suspicious is that some people are untrustworthy, and can add extra variables into a vaccine. It would be smart to take advantage of a treatment that directly and openly infects a person, with people doing it willingly. The big thing these days is the Covid vaccine. The people administering it say it's okay, but other research shows it's genetically modifying. Rather than being said small dose of the disease.

This bit is my personal opinion. Covid in the past has only been shown to have the mortality rate people express, when joined with other factoring diseases, and variables like old age. While it's an aggressive virus, it's wildly unsuccessful in causing actual death. Although strangely enough, it seems to affect people differently at random. My uncle caught it and had a pretty bad time. Made a full recovery like nothing happened, don't worry. But then in others, the worst they've had was it just being as bad as a cold. So my conclusion is that it's a disease that can be fought without a vaccine. It's extremely infectious, so we should respect it and take appropriate care of ourselves, but it's 'overhyped'. Plus, sources from all over have so many conflicting things to say, so it's hard to know what to trust. So I say, trust your own judgment, while taking heed of what all sources say. Without taking it as truth.
